awd_titl_txt: Conference: 27th GLOBE Annual Meeting: GLOBE Science Opens Global Benefits
awd_abstract_narration:
The GLOBE Program community has over the past 28 years created an openly accessible database with over 233 million measurements and growing at an increasing rate of almost 2 million submissions per month. As the program continues to grow, it needs to build on the success of the past as it attempts to address current challenges and others that may lie ahead. The 2023 Globe meeting will focus on Open Science, contributing to sponsors’ strategic objectives. Thus, GLOBE plans to increase its impacts beyond its community and into the wider Earth and Space Science and science education communities. 

The GLOBE Program’s measurement databases are freely accessible. As one of the core principles of Open Science, the 2023 Annual meeting will address how GLOBE program elements exemplify the principles of Open Science and align with sponsoring Agency priorities around data accessibility. Meeting sessions will explore and address the theme Open Science through the following strands: 1. Mobilizing Beyond Borders; 2. In and Beyond Classrooms; 3. Mapping Beyond Dots; and 4. Open Science Benefits the Environment/Society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 27th GLOBE Annual Meeting was held in Denver, CO, between 17 and 21 July, 2023. It gathered 245 participants from 40 GLOBE member countries to address the theme of ‘GLOBE Science Opens GLOBAL Benefits’. Participants included 31 GLOBE teachers and 30 middle and high school students who were selected through their participation in GLOBE student research symposiums. There were participants from all six GLOBE regions. The meeting became a place of collaboration, learning, and stewardship for hundreds of attendees from the GLOBE Community.

Over the meeting’s week-long course, attendees participated in presentations, workshops, and off-site excursions that showcased the meeting’s theme: “GLOBE Science Opens Global Benefits.” Sessions demonstrated use of GLOBE data in classrooms, telling stories through research and data visualization, and building connections among members both inside GLOBE’s diverse community and outside to new groups. In total there were 50 presentations by community members, in formats including lightning talks, traditional presentations, hands-on activities, panel discussions and symposia. During the poster presentation session on the first night of the meeting, all the 30 student participants shared posters of their work and there were an additional 21 posters presented by the wider GLOBE community. Through the four days of the conference key sessions were recorded and shared on social media and the GLOBE Youtube channel. 

A prominent feature of the Annual Meeting were three keynote presentations by experts in various science fields. Dr. Leila Farhadi (Associate Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering, The George Washington University) spoke on space-based and field site observations of the terrestrial water cycle. Dr. Scott McIntosh (Deputy Director of the National Center for Atmospheric Research - NSF NCAR) presented on solar physics, the history of eclipses and the April, 2024 solar eclipse in the US. Dr. Victoria Metcalf (Principal Advisor of Vocational Education and Training, New Zealand Tertiary Education Commission) spoke about Antarctic education and global relationships stemming from it. A special session titled “Contextualizing GLOBE for Indigenous Communities” was also held, exploring GLOBE protocols and best practices through weaving with indigenous communities’ knowledge systems. Participants were also able to attend a training on accessibility.

Students that attended the meeting took part in many activities, including: presenting their GLOBE research; data collection at Denver’s Metropolitan State University (MSU) campus and the Learning Lab; tours of the Denver Museum of Nature and Science and NCAR Mesa Lab; and a session at Denver’s History Colorado Center. Other attendees also had the chance to participate in off-site experiences, including tours of the MSU Auraria Campus Solar Array and NSF NCAR Mesa Lab, and a “GLOBE Gives Back” clean-up of Denver’s Cherry Creek. 

A highlight of the Annual Meeting was a presentation by the Moon Tree Foundation, where President Rosemary Roosa (daughter of NASA Astronaut Stuart Roosa) spoke about the history of Moon Trees. A sapling sycamore (moon tree descendent variety) was dedicated and was planted at the NSF NCAR Mesa Lab on Arbor Day, 2024. 

The evaluation survey administered at the end of the meeting found that 82% of respondents ‘strongly agreed’ or ‘agreed’ that they learned more about open science. There were many positive comments about the organization of the Meeting and coherence of the schedule, which allowed maximum participation. Here is the feedback from one evaluation survey respondent: It's my first in person Annual meetings. The meeting is well organized. There were various mini-workshops which allowed me to have many experiences and share experiences in different countries, which also allowed me to see different teachers, students, different members of GLOBE and to exchange with them about problems or uses of GLOBE tools on different protocols. It is an honor for me as the teacher to take part in the visit of NCAR which is almost a dream for science teachers like me. Thank you GLOBE !!. It is a good initiative that is worth all the gold in the world. I really appreciate it. This will also allow me to participate in the improvement of my teaching and GLOBE activities as well as the activities of my STEM club.
